GameEventAction.Description:
Once, the stories say, the Dhayut roamed the stars, seeking advantage, scheming our way toward clever victories, and deceiving those who had no defenses against our guile. Our complex plans confounded all lesser species, and we conquered the stars, leaving all others to wonder at our greatness. Inferior species trembled before us, but at the moment of our greatest victory, a terrible Cataclysm struck, destroying all we had built.
If the stories are true, then this welcoming, arid world was not our original home. Ancient artifacts we have recently discovered may confirm the truth of our legends, but legends only scratch the surface of truth. There is more of our past we must learn.
These relics of a distant past have inspired our greatest minds to repeat the glories of ancient times. Now that our scientists have discovered the means by which we can reach for the stars, we can spread out into the great void and regain all that was lost. Perhaps we will encounter other species and make them subservient to us, as our ancestors did. None will have the means to stand against the Dhayut. Clever and subtle victories await us. The stars will belong to the Dhayut in the future, just as they did in the past.

We have made a fascinating discovery! Under the surface of this world, we encountered the remains of an ancient structure, seemingly built by Dhayut. More evidence of our long-ago greatness! We must find a way to gain access to this facility so we can learn what knowledge from the past can be used to advance our goals now.
It may be possible to use simple explosives to blast our way in, but doing so could damage some of the structure, perhaps destroying the very knowledge and power we crave. Our engineers say they have an alternative would be to hack into the ancient computers and force the doors open, but these engineers are greedy, and must be bribed to perform this task. It is, after all, the Dhayut way to always seek advantage. The hacking will not be inexpensive, but it would be a cleaner method of gaining entrance.

GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Bribe the engineers to hack their way in 15,000cr

GameEventAction.Description:
As we feared, the explosion damaged a large portion of the facility. Even so, we have discovered much of value. This was a base built by an ancient civilization calling itself the Dhayut Web. These Dhayut, our ancestors, built a culture that spanned the stars, destroying, defeating, and deceiving all enemies. And yet, they fled some terrible danger, as though even the mighty Dhayut could be left with no scheme but to scramble for survival. The records are unclear, so we can only conclude these Dhayut were faced with whatever natural force caused the Cataclysm. A survey map marks our homeworld as being of particular interest, so it is logical to conclude that these were the same Dhayut that settled {16}.
The explosives damaged a large portion of the structure containing a research lab and a ship hangar. The research lab has been utterly destroyed, and we can gain nothing from the ruins. One of the four ships in the hangar was obliterated, but the other three are in excellent shape. We will take the bounty of our forebears, making the conquest of the stars all the easier.

Our crafty engineers were successful! They have opened the doors to this base, which was built by an ancient civilization calling itself the Dhayut Web. This was a culture that spanned the stars, destroying, defeating, and deceiving all enemies. And yet, they ran from something, as though even the mighty Dhayut could be made to tremble with fear. We can only conclude they fled whatever natural force caused the Cataclysm. A survey map marks our homeworld as being of particular interest, so it is logical to conclude that these were the same Dhayut that settled {16}.
Within we have also found the decayed remnants of a weapons research lab. This will certainly aid us.
We have also found a ship hangar, with four excellent and well-preserved vessels within. We will take the bounty of our forebears, making the conquest of the stars all the easier.
Our engineers have done well, but a question remains: do we praise their self-serving demand to be paid, or in this new era of exploration and expansion, must we punish those who cling to the traditional value of selfishness?

Let all Dhayut kind celebrate the ingenuity of our engineers, who not only discovered a means of safely entering the ancient facility, but also displayed admirable selfishness by demanding to be paid for their efforts.
Corruption on {18} has increased as a result.

In a public ceremony, we have executed the engineers for refusing to put the interests of all Dhayut above their own self-serving schemes. After their deaths, we praised their efforts, for the work is appreciated even if the workers are condemned.
Corruption on {18} has decreased, but so too has our scientist's work ethic.

We have found a strange alien ship belonging to a species whose shape is disgusting even to contemplate. On our homeworld, our philosophers have begun to debate the question of how these creatures did not choose self-genocide.
Curiously, we have been able to decipher at least part of their language, which is related to an ancient tongue of our own world. Some of their words have no Dhayut equivalent, but we believe the vessel belonged to a faction called Vulnerable Farming Tool, though that is only a best guess.
There are fragmented references to our own world in what remains in our log, and we can only conclude this ship was on its way to attack us. They must have been stupid as well as ugly to believe they could defeat our all-powerful ancestors.
The universe, however, cares nothing for the arrogance of foolish inferiors. The ship encountered a powerful natural force that sent it crashing to the surface, destroying all life on board. The ship was almost certainly destroyed by the same Cataclysm that brought down our ancestors' empire.
The ship was constructed with powerful security precautions, suggesting these disgusting creatures had the capacity for caution. Attempting to access certain portions of the ship will set off a self-destruct sequence. We must now decide if we wish to retrieve whatever remains in the cargo bay or attempt to access the main databanks and learn more of these aliens and their vile purpose.

In the ship's cargo bay we have discovered a large supply of Caslon, which will be of use as we expand outward and take our rightful place as master of everything. Some additional logs in the cargo bay reference a species called the Shakturi. The aliens feared them, but that tells us little. These creatures likely feared everything.

In the databanks we have learned that an ancient species called the Shakturi terrified the creatures who piloted this ship. This would be meaningless to us, since the creatures' appearance suggest they were cowardly by nature, but there are some troubling references to Dhayut in the data. It is by no means clear, but the implication is that the Shakturi used the Dhayut as expendable soldiers sent into battle for no other purpose but to soften up the Shakturi's foes. Perhaps these Shakturi were pirates who captured individual, isolated and vulnerable Dhayut and enslaved them. It cannot be that the Shakturi threatened our ancestors as a whole.
We have also found some information about medical technology, which these aliens evidently prized.

Fascinating. We have discovered on this world yet another crashed ship belonging to the Vulnerable Farming Tool aliens. We believe this vehicle was dedicated to scientific study, which would be unremarkable if their studies did not seem particularly focused on the Dhayut. We have discovered files discussing which environments are most hospitable for Dhayut. Were these aliens engaged in grotesque experiment upon the ancient Dhayut, manipulating their habitats to see the effects? These questions are made more pressing by the presence of a star chart in the wreckage. Our own home system is marked as being of particular interest.
But we cannot spend our time worrying about alien crimes of the distant past. We have a galaxy to conquer, after all. We believe we can reverse engineer certain aspects of this ship, though the process will be destructive. We must decide which technology is of most interest to us.

These aliens were vile but not without cleverness. By studying their ship, we have learned a great deal about their engine tech. In addition, we have determined that this world is well suitable for colonization.

These aliens were vile, and no doubt their cowardice led to the development of advanced shielding techniques. We can use their craven ingenuity to our own advantage. In addition, we have determined that this world is well suitable for colonization.

We have discovered the wreckage of an ancient science vessel operated by the Ikkuro faction known as the Peaceful Scythe. Very little remains of their logs, but it appears the ship crashed here when attempting to establish a base for researching the Dhayut. As this world is suitable for Dhayut habitation, it may be they intended to create a colony to study or even experiment upon. It is all very troubling.
The crashed ship is sophisticated beyond our own current technology. It will be worth our time to take it apart and study it, but our engineers believe that the intensive destruction required in the process means we can only focus on one type of technology. We must hope to gain knowledge of their use of engines or shields.
Our ancestors understood far more about engine mechanics than we currently do. We have learned a great deal from studying this ship.
Our ancestors understood far more about shield mechanics than we currently do. We have learned a great deal from studying this ship.

We have discovered a crashed science vessel of alien origin. The vessel is sophisticated beyond our own current technology. It will be worth our time to take it apart and study it, but our engineers believe that the intensive destruction required in the process means we can only focus on one type of technology. We must hope to gain knowledge of their use of engines or shields.
These aliens understood far more about engine mechanics than we currently do. We have learned a great deal from studying this ship.
These aliens understood far more about shield mechanics than we currently do. We have learned a great deal from studying this ship.

This world appears to be inhabited aliens who seem similar to those we found in the wreckage we discovered in our home system, but preliminary examination suggests they are not as advanced as we are. We would be wise to proceed with the subtlety so valued by our kind.
We are suspicious of you

It is as we cleverly surmised. This world is inhabited by creatures who call themselves Ikkuro. They claim to know nothing of the aliens whose ship we found in our home system, but they do know something of us. They are guarded and ask us again and again if we favor conflict or "the absence of conflict." We do not understand the question, but it makes us suspicious.
It is clear these inferior creatures have knowledge of our past, but our greatest minds are divided on the best means of extracting this information. The aliens appear to be fearful creatures, so we cannot tell them of our true nature. We can attempt to deceive them, but like all cowards, they will likely be skilled at seeing through falsehoods, and we will have to invest in better understanding their culture before we can attempt this. Alternatively, though their world is well defended, we can launch a surprise attack. This approach will also be costly.

After utilizing several xeno-exploitation experts to study the alien culture, we have gained a sufficient understanding to attempt to deceive the creatures. They have ancient accounts of "conflict averse" Dhayut, and though we do not fully understand how such Dhayut could exist, we have claimed to be the docile creatures they imagine.
Thus far, it appears our deception has worked. The aliens have explained that in ancient times, there were indeed two types of Dhayut: those who did not make war, like us (ha ha!) and violent, untrustworthy Dhayut who made common cause with powerful invaders called the Shakturi.
Perhaps they know more, but we do not believe we can press them without revealing our true nature.
We also do not understand why the all-powerful Dhayut Web would have allied themselves with these Shakturi. Our ancestors likely were pursuing a scheme to exploit the Shakturi, but we cannot be certain. We may be certain, however, that in the end all truths will be discovered.
The locals have given us the location of a Ikkuro colony world they believed to be of strategic interest to the Shakturi. They tell us that long ago their spies uncovered a password for avoiding this world's security systems. It will be useful if we pursue our investigation there.
On the homeworld, our people rejoice at our success in deceiving the aliens. Truly our glory days have returned.
We believe you are "conflict averse" Dhayut

Though this world is well-defended, we have launched a surprise attack and raided several locations before the risk/reward ratio made retreat the true victory. The aliens possess ancient accounts of "conflict averse" Dhayut, and though we do not fully understand what this means. We do know that the aliens have legends in which they appear as gods, reshaping other species to suit their own needs. It is, of course, nonsensical to believe that these quaking cowards could have "reshaped" the ancient Dhayut. Further proof of our former greatness is certainly to be found among the stars.
We have also stolen some of their supplies which will offset the cost of this operation.
We captured some of the locals, whom we tortured initially simply for entertainment, but we discovered they possessed information of interest. The have revealed the location of a Ikkuro colony world they believed to be of strategic interest to the Shakturi. Perhaps we can discover more of our past there.
You raided us!
The hivemind species that inhabits this world has shown a great deal of interest in our explorers. They treat us with reverence and respect. That is something we can exploit.

We are receiving a message form the planet surface.
"We greet you, our old masters. We, the Boskara of {0} have not forgotten out prosperous subordination to you, the Shakturi. We welcome your return, for you were once the great masters of the galaxy, and all other species trembled before you. We remember well watching as you stretched out across this region, using your pathetic slaves, the Dhayut, as cannon fodder. We hope such glorious days return."
Troubling. It cannot be that the Dhayut were once subordinate to the Shakturi. Clearly these aliens must be mistaken.
There is much debate among our leaders. Do we attempt to deceive the Boskara in order to exploit them, or do we pillage their world to disabuse them of their foolish mistake? Our failure to respond to our message is making the locals uneasy. We must determine a course of action at once.

We have plundered the several storehouses of these foolish aliens before our strategic retreat. They will never again mistake the Dhayut for other aliens, and now they will tremble when they hear our name.
You pillaged us!

We have begun a subterfuge program. Sophisticated, ongoing deception is never easy or inexpensive. We have made some inroads, but there are some who believe continuing will yield little results. Do we wish to follow this clever trickery to its logical end, or should we attempt to take what we can and pursue our conquest elsewhere?

We have made enough inroads in the Boskara culture that when we chose to withdraw, we were able to take with us enough valuables to cover the cost of our investment and even earn a little bit of a profit. We can declare this operation a glorious success.
We know you stole from us!
We have made inroads with some influential Boskaran locals on {0}, but suspicion of our nature and our motives is growing. We cannot continue this program without further investment.

We have plundered the several storehouses of these foolish aliens before our strategic retreat. They will never again mistake the Dhayut for other aliens, and now they will tremble when they hear our name.
We know you stole from us!

Success on {0}! We have convinced the locals that we are their masters. We have manipulated their simple hiveminds into believing we are Shakturi. We have altered their historical records, so all future generations will recognize us at once as their rightful masters. The aliens now shower us with praise and riches, and the world is ours for the taking should we want it.
We believe you are our ancient masters

This world is protected by an ancient forcefield which our engineers are unable to penetrate. Fortunately, the foolish Ikkuro of Devlin provided us with the password to deactivate it. Our cleverness once again provides us with a victory.

This world is protected by an ancient forcefield which our engineers are unable to penetrate. If only we had tortured the Ikkuro of Devlin longer, they might have given us a password. Lesson learned.
It may be possible to overload the forcefield and cause it to fail by applying a massive energy surge. This process, however, will be expensive. We will also have to act quickly if we wish to explore this world. Our probes have triggered a cascading effect which will cause the forefield to fail regardless of our actions, but if we do not deactivate it immediately, anything of value remaining on the surface will be destroyed.

This world is protected by an ancient forcefield which our engineers are unable to penetrate.
It may be possible to overload the forcefield and cause it to fail by applying a massive energy surge. This process, however, will be expensive. We will also have to act quickly if we wish to explore this world. Our probes have triggered a cascading effect which will cause the forefield to fail regardless of our actions, but if we do not deactivate it immediately, anything of value remaining on the surface will be destroyed.
It may be possible to overload the forcefield and cause it to fail by applying a massive energy surge. This process, however, will be expensive.
We have successfully deactivated the forcefield. We may now proceed to explore the planet.
We have saved our money for better things. Likely there was nothing of interest on that world.

With the forcefield deactivated, we have continued our exploration of Ingo. It appears to have once been inhabited by vile Ikkuro. All signs indicate there was once a large population present with expansive settlements, but all was destroyed by massive seismic activity. Another world, it seems, that fell to the great Cataclysm.
Very little remains intact on this world, and very little will survive the process of examination. The fragility of the ruins and data banks means we must focus our attention on examining only one aspect of the remaining technology.

In the ruins we have recovered a databank discussing the of many species involved in the great war against the Shakturi. It lists several species and the numbers involved in their migration. Among those fleeing the Shakturi are listed the Dhayut. "Their warlike and deceptive ways proved to be their downfall," a fragment reads.
This is clearly Ikkuro propaganda. The Dhayut would not flee like cowards. There is no enemy that cannot be deceived into becoming an ally. As logic tells us that the Dhayut Web could not have been made to flee, we can safely dismiss this information as false.
We have, however discovered much regarding weapons technology. For cowards, these Ikkuro were quite clever.

In the ruins we have recovered a databank discussing the of many species involved in the great war against the Shakturi. It lists several species and the numbers involved in their migration. Among those fleeing the Shakturi are listed the Dhayut. "Their warlike and deceptive ways proved to be their downfall," a fragment reads.
This is clearly Ikkuro propaganda. The Dhayut would not flee like cowards. There is no enemy that cannot be deceived into becoming an ally. As logic tells us that the Dhayut Web could not have been made to flee, we can safely dismiss this information as false.
We have, however discovered much regarding defensive technology. We can make good use of their cowardly science.

This world is protected by an ancient forcefield which our engineers are unable to penetrate.
It may be possible to overload the forcefield and cause it to fail by applying a massive energy surge. This process, however, will be expensive. We will also have to act quickly if we wish to explore this world. Our probes have triggered a cascading effect which will cause the forefield to fail regardless of our actions, but if we do not deactivate it immediately, anything of value remaining on the surface will be destroyed.
We have successfully deactivated the forcefield. We may now proceed to explore the planet.
A world, even a lifeless world, should be regarded as a living thing and so ought not to be contained. Whatever is below is likely lifeless and without interest.

Now that we have deactivated the forcefield on Ingo, we have discovered that this world once held a large Ikkuro population with several expansive cities, but all was destroyed by massive seismic activity. Another world, it seems, that fell to the great Cataclysm.
Very little remains intact on this world, and very little will survive the process of examination. The fragility of the ruins means we must focus our attention on examining only one element of their remaining technology.

In the ruins we have recovered a databank discussing the of many species from the great war against the Shakturi. Our ancestors were particularly interested in tracking the movement of the Dhayut. "Their warlike and deceptive ways caught up to them," a fragment reads.
We have, however discovered much regarding weapons technology.

In the ruins we have recovered a databank discussing the of many species from the great war against the Shakturi. Our ancestors were particularly interested in tracking the movement of the Dhayut. "Their warlike and deceptive ways caught up to them," a fragment reads.
We have, however discovered much regarding defensive technology.

This world is protected by an ancient forcefield which our engineers are unable to penetrate.
It may be possible to overload the forcefield and cause it to fail by applying a massive energy surge. This process, however, will be expensive. We will also have to act quickly if we wish to explore this world. Our probes have triggered a cascading effect which will cause the forefield to fail regardless of our actions, but if we do not deactivate it immediately, anything of value remaining on the surface will be destroyed.
We have successfully deactivated the forcefield. We may now proceed to explore the planet.
We have saved our money for more urgent purposes.

This world appears to have once held a large Ikkuro population with several expansive cities, but all was destroyed by massive seismic activity. Another world, it seems, that fell to the great Cataclysm.
Very little remains intact on this world, and very little will survive the process of examination. The fragility of the ruins means we must focus our attention on examining only one element of their remaining technology.

In the ruins we have recovered a databank discussing the of many species from the great war against the Shakturi. The Ikkuro were particularly interested in tracking the movement of the Dhayut. "Their warlike and deceptive ways caught up to them," a fragment reads.
We have, however discovered much regarding weapons technology.

In the ruins we have recovered a databank discussing the of many species from the great war against the Shakturi. The Ikkuro were particularly interested in tracking the movement of the Dhayut. "Their warlike and deceptive ways caught up to them," a fragment reads.
We have, however discovered much regarding defensive technology.
This world, ravaged by seismic damage, was once inhabited by countless Dhayut. There may be some remnants of the ancient Dhayut culture. We must pursue a diligent search.

In the ruins of a research lab, we have discovered a few dozen Dhayut in cryosleep chambers. As luck would have it, their energy supply remains stable, and our scientists believe we can revive the survivors if we so choose.
But should we? There is no knowing what contagions of the ancient galaxy these survivors might carry. And not all contagions are physical. We know that some ancient Dhayut were cowards, turned against their nature by the evil application of science, making them docile and subservient to weaker species. Could these be such Dhayut, and, if so, could their nature infect our pure Dhayut culture? Perhaps it is better to let the sleepers die and tear this equipment apart to learn what we can from it.
Yet, they may also know technological secrets of the past. The Dhayut at the time of the cataclysm were far more advanced than we were. What advantages will we deny ourselves if we do not seize this opportunity?
GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Examine equipment and let the sleepers die

GameEventAction.Description: By examining and disassembling the cryosleep equipment as well as the rest of the research lab, we have stumbled upon many useful secrets of the past. Moreover, we do not have to worry about what foul ideas the ancient Dhayut might have spread among our kind. Let the dead stay dead.

Good news. These Dhayut are very much like we are. They hold dear to core values of our culture: violence, deception, subtlety. Moreover, one of the survivors is an esteemed scientist of her own time. Her knowledge could be of much use to us, but while her character is beyond reproach, the historical events of which she speaks are troubling. She describes a galaxy in chaos in which the Dhayut were but one refugee faction among many. All fled, she tells us, before both the unstoppable Shakturi as well as the enemies of the Shakturi. Even worse, she says that the Dhayut were the authors of their own destruction, though she appears reluctant to say more. Perhaps the events traumatized her.
It may be a mistake to let this scientist converse with other, contemporary Dhayut. Her abilities are valuable, but she could spread dissent or doubt. It may be better simply to torture her for her knowledge and then put her to death.

GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Release scientist to continue her research

GameEventAction.Description: The scientist was, indeed, of strong moral character and resisted telling us very much. At least, not at first. In the end, all submit to pain. We are as nature made us.

We will allow the scientist to conduct her research and hope her research skills are more valuable than her knowledge of history is dangerous. Though we will give her a stern warning not to speak of the past.

Much as we feared, the scientist is spreading her tales of destruction wherever she goes. She speaks of the Dhayut today repeating the mistakes of the past. Moreover, she believes the Shakturi will return to destroy us all. Though she is undoubtedly of use to our research efforts, she creates a bit of a toxic work environment. We have assigned her a Dhayut resources officer to help her. Hopefully she will learn to not to upset her colleagues further, but we fear it is too late to contain this knowledge.
This world, ravaged by seismic damage, was once inhabited by countless Dhayut. There may be some remnants of the ancient Dhayut culture, and perhaps we can learn something from them.

In the ruins of a research lab, we have discovered a few dozen Dhayut in cryosleep chambers. As luck would have it, their energy supply remains stable, and our scientists believe we can revive the survivors if we so choose.
But should we? These are not pacified Dhayut. They are unlikely to wish to tell us much. They may prove violent or spread an illness from the past. We might learn a great deal form merely examining the cryochambers and allowing these ancient Dhayut to remain in the past. Still, life must be valued, and it is for each individual to choose its rightful path.
GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Examine equipment and let the sleepers die

GameEventAction.Description:
Life is of value, but so is harmony. It is better to serve life and the Ikkuro way than to elevate a few individuals above the good of the whole.
Our scientists have studied the ancient cryochambers and learned much. We have disposed of the sleepers in accordance with Dhayut burial rituals. It seemed the right thing to do.

The Dhayut we awakened have proved to be extremely hostile. Several of them overwhelmed our security team and attempted to escape from this world. A fierce battle ensued, and all of the Dhayut, sadly, died. Violence begets violence. It is ever thus. We have learned a valuable lesson: it is arrogant to expect other beings to act according to our own nature. They must act according to their nature. That is the harmony of the galaxy.
Most of the cryochambers were destroyed in the firefight, but our scientists were able to gain some knowledge by examining the wreckage.
This world, ravaged by seismic damage, was once inhabited by countless Dhayut. There may be some remnants of the ancient Dhayut culture, and perhaps we can learn something from them.

In the ruins of a research lab, we have discovered a few dozen Dhayut in cryosleep chambers. As luck would have it, their energy supply remains stable, and our scientists believe we can revive the survivors if we so choose.
But should we?
GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Examine equipment and let the sleepers die

GameEventAction.Description: Our scientists have studied the ancient cryochambers and learned much.

The Dhayut we awakened have proved to be extremely hostile. Several of them overwhelmed our security team and attempted to escape from this world. A fierce battle ensued, and all of the Dhayut, were killed. There is an old expression our historians have uncovered from ancient times. "Let sleeping Dhayut remain asleep." As it turns out, this is not a metaphor.
Most of the cryochambers were destroyed in the firefight, but our scientists were able to gain some knowledge by examining the wreckage.

This is the homeworld of the ancient Dhayut Web, destroyed by the Cataclysm. Here we will no doubt learn the secrets of our ancient empire. Once we absorb those lessons, our own triumph will be but a matter of time.

There is some troubling news from the surface. It seems our battle with the Gravillex has caused debris to fall to the planetary surface, damaging some of the few remaining buildings. Based on our analysis of ancient Dhayut protocol, we are certain that in a matter of minutes, a distress call will be issued from the governmental complex. This appears to be linked to a contingency plan in the event the Dhayut were overwhelmed by an enemy. That was clearly not what happened, since no aliens could defeat the Dhayut, but the distress call may now alert others to the existence of this world. We cannot risk other species gaining control of our people's ancient treasures.
At the same time, there are fires raging in the one remaining research facility, one of the few remaining structures left standing on the surface. If we don't get the fires under control, we will lose some of what remains of value there. We only have the resources to address one of these problems immediately.

We have been able to stop the distress signal from being deployed. We may now explore the research facility. In the ruins of the governmental complex, we have discovered a statue called the Great Deceiver. It is an homage to all the great Dhayut who have enslaved and manipulated weak and cowardly aliens, and it reveals lost secrets of how to plot against the inferior inhabitants of the galaxy.

We eventually put out the fires as well and have now explored the research facility. It was extensively damaged, but we were still able to salvage much from the remains of the wreckage. We have discovered an ancient data crystal called The Threads of Research, a revolutionary approach to the scientific process. This will bring much wisdom to our scientists. Establishing a research base here to continue the ancients' work would be wise.

We have decided the ancient research facility was simply too important to be lost. We will have to risk aliens learning of the existence of this world. If they dare to stake a claim upon it, we will deal with them.
We have now explored the research facility. We have discovered an ancient manual called The Threads of Research, a revolutionary approach to the scientific process. This will bring much wisdom to our scientists. Establishing a research base here to continue the ancients' work would be wise.
Even though we were too late to stop the distress signal, we have sent a small team to the governmental complex to see if there is anything there worth salvaging. We have discovered a statue called the Great Deceiver. It is an homage to all the great Dhayut who have convinced aliens to sign disadvantageous deals.

Horror! An examination of the wreckage has revealed much data from the time before the Cataclysm, and little of it comports with our understanding of history. Our world was not destroyed by the uncontrolled natural forces that emerged after our triumph. It was not even destroyed by the final battle with the Shakturi the fate that befell most of the galaxy. No, our world was destroyed by the horrific battle when the Ikkuro invaded. They held us in particular contempt and marked us as too dangerous to be tolerated within their strange and twisted philosophy. Of course, when we invaded, we fought back ferociously, perhaps participating in the planetary devastation. The Ikkuro were too timid to set out to destroy this world entirely. It may well be our resistance forced them to act more decisively.
We have learned that the Dhayut web sided with the Shakturi invaders, but only for the purpose of eventually overthrowing them. To prove our worth, we left a path of destruction across the galaxy. It seems that this was too much for the conflict averse Ikkuro, who were roused from their torpor and destroy us. Then came a horrible turn of events, as the Shakturi discovered our plans and enslaved all of the Dhayut Web. With no choice but to obey our powerful masters, the Dhayut became even more destructive, devastating even more worlds. Thus the Ikkuro began their campaign against our species.
This information cannot be allowed to spread. By executing a handful of brave explorers and researchers, we believe we can keep these troubling facts contained. Only those at the highest level of government can be trusted with the dark secret. The Dhayut Web did not once dominate the galaxy. It was defeated by lesser beings.
We cannot let this knowledge diminish our ambitions. We have learned much from the ruins of our homeworld, uncovering important secrets of the past. We have found an inspiring painting called The Clever Steward, which contains images that will help make our defense facilities less expensive to maintain. More than all of this, we will learn from past rather than be chastened by it. Our ancestors may have fallen to their enemies. We shall not. Their failure shall lead the way to our own success. The belief in the Dhayut triumphant was not fantasy. No, it was prophecy.

We have discovered the ancient homeworld of the Dhayut web. Much of the world is damaged, but we have managed to locate a relatively preserved research facility. The Dhayut way of thinking is alien to us, but nevertheless, there is much to be gained by attempting to understand foreign cultures.
We have been able to learn more of this world's history. It seems the Ikkuro itself caused much of the destruction here as we invaded to stop the Dhayut, who had become Shakturi puppets, from pursuing their path of destruction across the galaxy, eliminating entire worlds. The Dhayut were determined to fight a scorched earth campaign on their own world, forcing the Ikkuro to use more aggressive measures than are usually desirable.
We have discovered a statue called the Great Deceiver. It is an homage to all the great Dhayut diplomats, even though their approach to diplomacy is sometimes hard to fathom.
Finally, we have found a painting called The Clever Steward which reveals much about the ancient Dhayut's knowledge of planetary defense systems.

We have discovered the ancient homeworld of the Dhayut web. Much of the world is damaged, but we have managed to locate a relatively preserved research facility. There we have The Dhayut way of thinking is alien to us, but nevertheless, there is much to be gained by attempting to understand foreign cultures.
